Just had lasik, i worse glasses for most of my life , give or take 15+ years. 

I still get the phantom glasses as i try to take it off now and then. But holy shit, what a relief to not wear glasses anymore, you can play sports, swim, wear sunglasses without prescription, even not get foggy glasses when you get out of a cold room.

The whole lasik operation took under 3 minutes for both eyes in total. And i was done for the day. Went back, went to sleep and woke up, looked for my glasses by my bedside table but i realized i could see now. 

The only regret it why didnt i do this sooner

Im gonna be honest, your car looking like that doesnt really help the mass consumers. The general public who buy second hand cars are looking for cars that has that standard look, slight modifications are fine. 

IMO if i was a buyer, in first glance i would think that this car is heavily used even if it wasnt. With it looking like this, you are practically cutting your consumer market by more than 50% as women, older people, working salaryman wouldnt buy a car that looks like this. Which you are left with are younger consumers & people who mod cars, which i would consider not a large market gap.

Yeah you are right, but it all boils down to financial capability at the end. I could go lower and cut costs, but every single aspect of my wedding was hand picked by both of us. In hindsight, the results from the wedding and the reception was more than satisfactory. Including my previous statement where i said we had to pick guests to be seated meticulously? We had a number of high profile guests that came to our party, these people have a keen eye on attires, jewelry, etc. As i said this was something of a social event. Both the bride and groom are the highlight of the night, as i am financially comfortable of it i would like my wife to go all out as you only experience your wedding once in a lifetime. Spending where we know its right but with the budget OP is stating, i would double check on what they are including

Yeah bro if it was up to me , i would have just wanted a simple 10 table with closest friends and family. But for Chinese, wedding is actually a social event. You have to invite who's who just to give them face, and also you have to pick where each guests have to be seated meticulously. For example, there is a guest who gave me around RM20K, we kinda know it beforehand so he has to sit really really close to the front

How is it RM500K for 50 tables bro, i just had my wedding 2 years back, a simple breakdown:

Wedding Dinner Including Hall Rental RM1588 per table for 45 tables(450 pax)=72K

Gown Rental (Pre Wedding Shoot Gown, Actual Day Bride and Groom)=10K

Photography Sessions Included for Pre Wedding, Tea Ceremony,Actual Day=10K

Betrothal gift, tea ceremony, dowry (Include Food, Inviting Guests for Dinner one day before Wedding= Estimate 25-30K

Wedding Ring & Engagement Ring = 30-35K

Wedding Decoration Including Home, Car, Wedding Hall = 20K

Ad Hoc= 10K

A rough estimate for me was 200K including everything, and i would consider my wedding to be expensive already. But we did not hire a wedding planner, we planned everything from day 1 to the wedding ourselves.

EDIT: The angpau from the wedding dinner did cover the wedding dinner and more. So the damage after subtracting the angpau is floating around 110K

Erwin smith - Attack On Titan 

Everything that you thought had meaning: every hope, dream, or moment of happiness. None of it matters as you lie bleeding out on the battlefield. None of it changes what a speeding rock does to a body, we all die. But does that mean our lives are meaningless? Does that mean that there was no point in our being born? Would you say that of our slain comrades? What about their lives? Were they meaningless?... They were not! Their memory serves as an example to us all! The courageous fallen! The anguished fallen! Their lives have meaning because we the living refuse to forget them! And as we ride to certain death, we trust our successors to do the same for us! Because my soldiers do not buckle or yield when faced with the cruelty of this world! My soldiers push forward! My soldiers scream out! My soldiers RAAAAAGE!
Watch Attack On Titan brother you will not regret

Decision Making

This is literally the one thing that dictates everything else. In life you are always given choices sometimes two, three, four choices. Among these choices, there is always the correct choice, the bad choice, the neutral choice. Sometimes you are aware on which choice is correct but you are held back emotionally and you choose the other way. Heck, even some wrong choices that you made wont be noticeable even after years.

Imagine this, your decision making is always correct. Which route to take to work, which stocks to buy, which commodity to invest, choosing the right ideas to expand your business, giving the right information to the right people. Compounding your correct decision making, heck you can even be the president if you play it right.

Thank you for your input , can I know what’s your temps for your rig ?

Your temps never hit more than 55 degrees even under heavy load , or it is idling temps

It really is a high ceiling for a learning curve, but once you start getting a grasp of the basics, everything is easier to understand. 

When i started, Dota Cinema had these things called Hero Introduction for each hero. I dont know why watching a hero performing a skill is much more easier to learn than reading it for me. I watched every single hero and i started learning the mechanics. I wouldnt recomend watching it in 2024 because there are major changes to some heroes. But yeah i have around 1000 hours in and i am still learning to this day.

Grasp the basics and literally just have fun. I would recommend playing turbo if you are a casual gamer. Gold and XP gains are 2X faster and also games end much faster. Playing a normal match after playing turbo is really draggy. Play with bots first and test different heroes to start out.

Bro how narrow minded are you? 
You are literally talking about one side of the story , I’m not defending Malaysian companies as I am a worker as well. I come from a low-middle class household. There are literally so many good Malaysian company owners out there, and I’m not even talking about Khairul Aming level. 

You are blatantly stating that ALL rich kids are entitled. I have multiple friends and people that I know who are some of the upper tiers but they are some of the best people you’d meet, of course they do post and show off, but I mean why can’t they? 

So through your logic only through government subsidies , exploiting workers can one get rich ? 
Does a fish market seller, hardware store owner, nasi lemak seller, all who earns more than 5 figures a month rely on government subsidies? If so do you think the government give them out to any and everyone? Bro make it make sense, they put themselves in that position to make themselves beneficial to the government for them to finance them.

Top 1% are the SDN BHD companies you see daily, be it coffee shop owners, restaurants owners, or even spare parts store owners. To be in the lower bracket of top 1% means earning RM25,000/month. Do you think that these people can open their store and leave? 

Oh and in addition to that, how many people with wealthy parents do all that, that you said that you know IRL. Or is it just 'something you heard from a friend of a friend'. Dont get me wrong, there are people like this, but mostly not to that extent. 

Oh and that point about rich parents, wouldnt any one of us done the same? If you have rich and supportive parents, wouldnt you take that advantage? I mean this is what their parents work for is it now? To build a better future for their kids? Its like owning a car but choosing not to use it because everyone uses a bike, like for what?  No one chooses their parents. If they are lucky enough to be born in a wealthier family, people like you will start to complain without knowing them personally. As ive said Malaysians are one of the kindest people out there.

Exactly my point, SDN BHD companies owners can earn ranging from 100K to a few million ringgit a month.

  
The elites makes money that we can only think off. Just based on googling their net worth or reading their companies financial statement isnt going to cut it as these are wealth that are published and listed.

A company might make 100K revenue a month but their costs is 90K netting them 10K, another might make 50K with a 50% net profit of 25K a month. Just by stating revenue doesnt really justify anything. There are good that are very high in price but low in margins and there are cheap goods that has a very big volume with high margin. 

As i said 50% profit margin of 10 cents is 15 cents, which might no look like much but through compounding and volume it beats a product which is RM100 with 5% profit margin.

Hi there, you are literally right.

As i have said before, there are loads of opportunities present in our homeland Malaysia. There are countless ways an average Malaysian can get money, you have online marketing (Instagram, Tiktok), globalization literally makes it super easy for anyone to get products from China, you can source items by a few clicks on your phone.  I am not saying that being the ultra wealthy is easy , it does take luck as well but being living comfortably is achievable. 

Another fact is that Malaysia has one of the kindest people in the world. You can actually walk up to a Mak Cik by the roadside stall, and they would talk to you like you are their own son, talking about their day. Not only that people are actually willing to share knowledge if you ask the right questions and being socially inept knowing how to approach people. I have sat down with people from all economic backgrounds and chat with them and how they made their wealth. Its surprising how some make money, i know one who makes millions producing fishnet, yes fishnets. Do not let a few bad apples ruin the whole basket. You cannot find people like Malaysians anywhere else.

Complaining does not do anyone good. Wealth inheritance is something no one can take control off. Comments here are saying everyone with a wealth inheritance also has a bad attitude, showing off their lifestyle. Heck, if anyone here had that they would too, could you blame them? But i also have friends who flaunt their wealth online but are the kindest and generous people ever. Everytime that i goes and stay over at his house, he demands that we must not pay even a single cent and that he has it covered even after insisting. He also always make a point to pay a few tens of ringgit to any beggars he sees on the street.

I might argue, that working smart is also a major factor.

Imagine hiring 2 people to file paperwork. 

Person 1: A hard worker, files it manually paper by paper does it 8 hours straight a day 5 days a week.

Person 2: A smart worker, uses a software to extract data and file it accordingly and does it within the hour.

Being a smart worker with inept problem solving skills really helps alot, as you are generally sought after more in the labor market, thus increasing your value and your salary in return.

A prime example, a very controversial figure, Carlos Ghosn who literally turned Nissan around through his vision and implementation. He is does not work hard (screws the bolts on the cars, move inventory, transport goods).

He build his reputation by being a problem solver and the only person who can do it efficiently.

The keyword 'mindset'

I fully agree on everything you just said. There are tons of opportunity in Malaysia to gain wealth, you can do literally anything and be well off, note well off not being ultra wealthy.

A pasar malam fish seller tells me he can make around 30-40K a month by just selling fish. Heck if you are not planning to start a business, you can literally live comfortably by being a property agent, insurance salesman, etc. There are loads of opportunities here.

Sure there are people who inherit wealth but can you blame them, their parents got wealth by working hard, do you think they would pass it down to someone outside the family. That is what they are working for, to provide and make a comfortable living for their families. Just complaining about wealth inheritance is not going to do anyone good. That is why i really agree with ' hardworking and a positive mindset'

I wouldnt agree with this, 

  
By this logic , you would have to set up a company, make sure cash flow sustains at a certain level and is sufficient to handle a number of employees to exploit.

  
I am not denying exploitation isnt real but you are talking about sweatshops level exploitation but i am talking about top 1% not the top 0.001%

Finally, someone who understands. 

People always say that rich people migrate overseas. No offend but actually no. I have seen and know a handful of 1% in Malaysia and most of them dont actually migrate to another country. Most of the have their roots buried deep in Malaysia. Plus they know the ins and outs of our Malaysian economy, legislation, taxation. 

When i talk about the top 1%, i am talking about the ones who have a very very comfortable and good income in the range of 100K to a few millions a month. Most of the comments are talking about the top 0.01% which has listed companies, ties to the government with conglomerates etc.

Starting a business in Malaysia is actually one of the easiest to go around, for example, there is shopee, instagram, tiktok. I have seen friends who saved up a few thousand ringgit in capital, sourced a few items from Taobao and literally rebranded it and took super good photos and videos of the items and sold it at a premium price locally here. Once your volume comes to a certain level, you can actually discuss with the factories in china to haggle the price , customize your own packaging, make custom items just catered to you.

  
That particular friend on a good month makes 150-200K after 10 years through trial and error, making a good amount of money. But also do take into consideration his costs takes up around 50% of his revenue.

  
The thing about being in Malaysia is you know the culture first hand and you know it quick. There are loads of opportunities here in Malaysia. Plus people are also very welcoming and supportive. Do not let a bad apple ruin the whole basket.

There are things that you dont see but hear before it happens, for example if a motorcycle horns you at a blind spot while you are initiating a turn, the horn alerts you of the impending issue.

  
I have tried using once or twice, but better to avoid before anything happens.
